meaning: A function you want to integrate.
The number 'a' that is at the bottom of the integral sign is called the lower limit of the integral, and the number 'b' at the top of the integral sign is called the upper limit of the integral.
Used to approximate the area under a simple curve.
A certain kind of approximation of an integral by a finite sum.
A theorem that links the concept of differentiating a function (calculating the gradient) with the concept of integrating a function (calculating the area under the curve).
Considers the integral of a rate of change.
A method for evaluating integrals and antiderivatives.
A finite section of a right circular cylinder.
A solid figure obtained by rotating a plane curve around some straight line (the axis of revolution) that lies on the same plane.
A means to finding the volume of a solid that has been created when the graph of a function is revolved about a line, usually the x or y axis.
A method for calculating the volume of a solid of revolution.
The mean of a function.
A special method of integration that is often useful when two functions are multiplied together, but is also helpful in other ways.
A family of integrals involving trigonometric functions.
A technique for evaluating integrals.
An algebraic fraction can be broken down into simpler parts.
A method used for dividing large numbers into groups or parts.
The numerator represents how many parts of that whole are being considered, while the denominator represents the total number of parts created from the whole.
An integration method which is often useful when the integrand is a fraction including more than one kind of root.
A definite integral that has either or both limits infinite or an integrand that approaches infinity at one or more points in the range of integration.
